verses.text: Surely there is a mine for silver, and a place where gold is refined.
verses.comment: Job begins this poetic passage with a reflection on humanity's ability to seek out and extract treasures from the earth. Literal reference to mining, but serves as a metaphor for searching for true wisdom. No significant difference from the Hebrew; key theme introduced.

verses.text: Iron is extracted from the earth, and copper is smelted from ore.
verses.comment: Job continues describing humanity’s ingenuity. These examples of technological progress set up a contrast with the elusive nature of wisdom itself.

verses.text: Man puts an end to darkness; he searches out places far and deep, stones in the gloom and shadow.
verses.comment: The passage highlights human determination and skill, venturing even beneath the earth where light doesn't reach. Symbolically, it hints at the spiritual pursuit for hidden truths.

verses.text: He breaks a shaft apart away from where people live; forgotten by travelers, they hang far from men, and swing to and fro.
verses.comment: Mining imagery, showing the lengths man goes for treasure. Spiritual readers see echoes of Jesus’ teaching about seeking the Kingdom (Matt. 13:44).

verses.text: The earth, from which bread comes, is turned beneath as by fire.
verses.comment: Contrasting earth's life-giving surface with its fiery, hidden depths. Subtle allusions to resurrection and transformation themes (John 12:24).

verses.text: Its stones are the source of sapphires, and it contains dust of gold.
verses.comment: Emphasis on precious stones and gold. The motif of searching for precious things mirrors the search for the pearl of great price (Matt. 13:45-46).

verses.text: No bird of prey knows that path; the falcon’s eye has not seen it.
verses.comment: Job notes that not even the most perceptive creatures see these paths; wisdom is above natural ability, requiring revelation.

verses.text: The proud beasts have not trodden it; no lion has passed over it.
verses.comment: Lion symbolizes strength and kingship. Even powerful creatures cannot find wisdom’s ways by their own might. See also Proverbs 8 for wisdom as a personified figure.

verses.text: Man stretches out his hand against the flinty rock, overturns mountains by the roots.
verses.comment: Imagery of human effort and ingenuity—yet the passage prepares to show that wisdom cannot be gained by labor alone, but requires divine gift.

verses.text: He cuts channels through the rocks, and his eye sees every precious thing.
verses.comment: Technical skill lauded, but foreshadows the deeper truth: no matter how far human effort goes, true wisdom remains elusive.

verses.text: He dams up streams from trickling, and brings hidden things to light.
verses.comment: Parallels with God’s revelation—man brings mysteries to light, but only God can reveal the fullness of truth. See Daniel 2:22.

verses.text: But where can wisdom be found, and where is the place of understanding?
verses.comment: Crux of the chapter: despite achievements, wisdom cannot be mined like earthly treasures. The question anticipates Christ as the fullness of wisdom (Col. 2:3).

verses.text: Man does not know its value; it is not found in the land of the living.
verses.comment: Wisdom is not an earthly commodity. The 'land of the living' suggests mortality’s limits. Points forward to heavenly wisdom revealed in Christ.

verses.text: The deep says, ‘It is not in me’; the sea says, ‘It is not with me.’
verses.comment: Even the most inaccessible places deny holding wisdom. All creation is insufficient without revelation from God. See James 1:5.

verses.text: It cannot be bought with gold, nor its price weighed out in silver.
verses.comment: Wisdom transcends all material wealth. Symbolically, wisdom is ultimately a gift, prefigured by the Spirit and fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: It cannot be valued with the gold of Ophir, with precious onyx or sapphire.
verses.comment: Reference to legendary wealth, emphasizing wisdom’s surpassing worth. Spiritual tradition sees wisdom as related to divine revelation.

verses.text: Gold and glass cannot equal it, nor can it be exchanged for jewels of fine gold.
verses.comment: ‘Glass’ (ancient Egypt) and ‘fine gold’ add vividness. Wisdom stands alone, not traded or measured by earthly valuables.

verses.text: No mention shall be made of coral or crystal; the price of wisdom is above pearls.
verses.comment: The pearl recalls Jesus’ parable of the pearl of great price. Spiritual meaning: wisdom is to be sought with all one’s heart.

verses.text: The topaz of Cush cannot compare with it; it cannot be valued in pure gold.
verses.comment: Allusions to priestly stones intensify the spiritual resonance, as true wisdom is linked to priesthood and divine mediation.

verses.text: So where then does wisdom come from, and where is the place of understanding?
verses.comment: Repeats the central question. Drives the reader to acknowledge the need for divine revelation, later fulfilled in Christ (John 1:9).

verses.text: It is hidden from the eyes of all living, concealed from the birds of the air.
verses.comment: Wisdom is inaccessible by natural means, suggestive of the hidden mysteries later revealed to the spiritual community (1 Cor. 2:7-10).

verses.text: Destruction and Death say, ‘We have heard a rumor of it with our ears.’
verses.comment: Even death has no full grasp of wisdom—anticipates Christ’s defeat of death and revelation of eternal truth (Rev. 1:18).

verses.text: God understands the way to it, and He knows its place.
verses.comment: Here, wisdom is rooted in God alone. Later Christian understanding sees the fullness of wisdom manifested in the person of Christ.

verses.text: For He looks to the ends of the earth and sees everything under the heavens.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience is celebrated. This divine attribute is foundational for later understanding of God’s providence and the sacramental life.

verses.text: When He established the wind’s weight and apportioned the waters by measure,
verses.comment: References creation; God’s ordering power suggests that wisdom is linked to His creative and sustaining Word. See John 1:1-3.

verses.text: when He made a decree for the rain and a path for the thunderbolt,
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over nature supports the teaching that wisdom comes from Him alone. Spiritual interpretation points to God’s ordering of all things for salvation.

verses.text: then He saw it and declared it; He established it and searched it out.
verses.comment: Wisdom is purposely established by God, not accidental. This prepares the reader for understanding the incarnation of ultimate Wisdom.

verses.text: And He said to mankind, ‘Look, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom, and to turn away from evil is understanding.’
verses.comment: The culmination: wisdom is a virtue rooted in ‘fear of the Lord’, which is both reverent devotion and practical obedience. Literal and spiritual interpretation converge—reverence, faith, and turning from sin are the pathways to wisdom. This message opens to the fullness of communion and sacramental living, central to Christian life. See James 3:17’s description of wisdom from above.
